title.narrative: Parliamentary Development for Social Policies (PDSP) Project

description.narrative: Strengthen capacities of AoK for evidence based formulation of socially inclusive policies and legislation, and establish an oversight mechanism.
capital of a political entity
Elections - elections

1. Number of women participants in the working groups, legal drafting and trainings (50% or more); number of issues related to women’s participation 2. Equal inclusion of women MPs in the budgetary issues (50%); Women NGOs or those with women leaders included in the partnership agreements 3. Equal representation of women and men (boys and girls) in workshops, town hall meetings; II. Increased interest in participation of women in new programmes and activities with NGOs and AoK

comment.narrative: 1. Lack of reliable evidence on social issues from the ground and lack of reliable mechanisms to inform the AoK and CSOs on SI agenda 2. Lack of web based information sharing system hampers institutional memory and progress on MDGs and Social inclusion. 3. Lack of regular public meetings with constituency enforces the perception of constituency on the disinterest of the government in being duly represented
Drafting AoK strategy in a gender-inclusive manner Support 12 Parliamentary Committees
AoK Strategy drafted in a gender inclusive manner and in compliance with HR approach 12 interns were placed with Parliamentary Committees to support the process of research and data collection

71 farmers (38% women) received direct support, 719 farmers supported with trainings and direct coaching; 105 benefited from experience-sharing study visits; 71 new jobs created (38% women).

description.narrative: Central and local level disaster coordination and communication enhanced.
The objective of the KDRRI is to support the government, civil society, and private sector in establishing a sustainable and effective DRR system at the national and local levels.
capital of a political entity
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

1. Level of progress made in drafting and revising DRR related legislation, policies and institutional structures. 2. # of coordinated efforts taken by the NP directly contributing towards DRR 3. % increase of resources allocated by the government towards DRR. 4. # of actions taken by national and local authorities based on risk assessments conducted. 5. # of mitigation, early warning and preparedness measures implemented based on the developed risk management plans. 6. % of citizens and public authorities using mobile phone application to report vulnerabilities and hazardous conditions and receive EW info. 7. % of municipalities in which risk assessment was completed. 8. % of community development plans with integrated gender sensitive DRR actions. 9. # of applications and approvals for local level mitigation projects and % of projects implemented.

comment.narrative: 1. Lack of national DRR strategy and outdated legal framework. 2. National level risk assessment last conducted in 2009. 3. Law on Protection against Natural and other Disasters is not gender sensitive and makes no reference to DRR. 4. Lack of coordination among two lead institutions in DRR (AEM and the Situation Centre). Vertical coordination between local and central level entities is also weak. 5. Risk assessment capacities are low and existing methodologies do not adequately integrate vulnerability and capacity assessments. 6. Linkages among DRR related entities for monitoring and emergency management require formal specification and strengthening. 7. There is no predefined/arranged methodology for the collection of information, storage and periodic updating of disaster related data. 8. Communities and municipalities lack capacity in disaster preparedness and prevention. 9. Limited available resources at the local level focus entirely upon disaster response and not prevention. 10. National and local authorities lack capacity to support risk management interventions.

- Finalization of the Disaster Risk Reduction Strategy. - Finalization of the review of the National Risk Assessment Document. - Finalization of the Disaster inventory management system - Desinventar. - Commemoration of the 13 October IDDR - Finalization of the infrastructural projects in northern municipalities. - Facilitation of the communication between northern firefighters and EMA

- DRR strategy first final draft is finalized. - The National Risk Assessment Document is finalized - DesInventar implemented and launched on 31 march 2015. - The international Day for DRR commemorated Kosovo wide. - All infrastructural projects in northern municipalities are finalized. - The regular communication and cooperation between EMA and northern firefighters is successfully implemented.

Finalise the Rules of Procedures and Action Plan to draft National Transitional Justice Strategy

The rules of procedure for Inter-Ministerial Working Group on Dealing with the Past and Reconciliation (IMWG DwPR) have been approved. Continues support to IMWG DwP and its Secretariat has been provided in the process of Strategy Drafting.
Progress made in drafting a Transitional Justice Strategy.
Draft Strategy on Transitional Justice.

Comments and interventions made by CSOs on drafts produced by Inter-Ministerial Working Group that are ultimately accepted into documents. Empowerment of the marginalized groups of minority communities for their engagement in Transitional Justice Process.

description.narrative: To create institutional and individual capacities in target Municipalities
policy, planning and administration
Number of municipal staff trained in economic and rural development activities

comment.narrative: Limited capacities of economic and rural development departments within the two targeted Municipalities

Target 1.1: 8 municipal staff trained in economic and rural development activities Target 1.2: 135 representatives (women and men) of local businesses, NGOs, associations and farmers trained in economic and rural development activities
Target 3.1: 183 jobs created/formalized through TEPs in the two municipalities Target 3.2: Women constitute 35% of TEP beneficiaries Target 3.3: 45 micro-enterprises upgraded through TEPs

Result 1.1: 91 municipal staff (12 women and 79 men) trained in economic and rural development activities 42 (9 women and 33 men) municipal officials from Štrpce/Shtërpcë municipality participated in trainings; 49 (3 women and 46 men) municipal officials from Dragash/Dragaš municipality participated in trainings; (Sources: GC&DA LLC final report on the implementation of the training) Result 1.2: 372 representatives (46 women and 326 men) of local businesses, NGOs, associations and farmers trained in economic and rural development activities 86 representatives (7 women and 79 men) of local businesses, 107 representatives (25 women and 82 men) of NGOs, 179 representatives (14 women and 165 men) of farmers are trained in economic and rural development. In addition, 206 participants (17 women and 189 men) participated in combined sessions for all target groups (Sources: GC&DA LLC final report on the implementation of the training)
Result 3.1: 299 jobs created/formalized through TEPs Result 3.2: Women as 28 % of TEP beneficiaries as direct recipients Result 3.3: 129 of rural micro-enterprises created or upgraded through TEPs

description.narrative: Creation of new jobs and income generation opportunities through an improved market positioning and productivity of local micro and small enterprises, including individual farmers in Municipalities of Štrpce/Shtërpcë and Dragash//Dragaš.
policy, planning and administration
Indicator 2.1: Number of functioning newly created and upgraded businesses

comment.narrative: 419 registered businesses in Shtërpcë/ Štrpce and 829 in Dragash/ Dragaš (Source: SME Agency)
Target 2.1: 20 of newly created and upgraded businesses functioning through the LDF grants

Out of 31, 9 of newly created and upgraded businesses functioning, are from the LDF First call grants of 2014/2015 in which, 1 of them is women-led; As such,the first LDF call (9 grants) produced: 37 jobs created, out of which, 31 are permanent self-employed jobs and 6 seasonal jobs; 27 are women and 10 are men; 19 are family members and 18 non-family members; 20 of these belong to non majority community. In the second LDF call, 22 grants are almost all implemented, (3 of them women-led; the second installments are almost finalized for all 22 granted projects for small holder farmers in the second round of grants. This depends also from the nature of the projects/grants and the implementation period, which for couple of grants is until spring 2016). The creation of jobs, to be reported at the end of Q4 and during Q1 in 2016.

participating-org.narrative: PROVISIONAL INSTITUTIONS OF SELF GOVERNMENT IN KOSOVO

description.narrative: policy, planning and administration

provider-org.narrative: PROVISIONAL INSTITUTIONS OF SELF GOVERNMENT IN KOSOVO
PROVISIONAL INSTITUTIONS OF SELF GOVERNMENT IN KOSOVO

description.narrative: IndicatorI.1: % of unemployed youth benefiting from ALMPs IndicatorI.2: % of women benefiting from almps IndicatorI.3: % of almps beneficiaries from minority communities

comment.narrative: BaselineI.1: 35% of unemployed youth (15-24 age group) benefit from almps (total beneficiaries in 2012 is 10,922) BaselineI.2: 30% of almps beneficiaries are women (2012) BaselineI.3: 10% of almps beneficiaries are from minority communities(2012)

TargetI.1: % youth (15-24) benefiting from almps is increased at least for 2% TargetI.2: % women benefiting from almps is increased at least for 7% TargetI.3: % almps beneficiaries from minorities is increased at least for 2%

Reform and Modernization of Public Employment Services o The Ministry of Labour and Social Welfare is able and has the tools to assess and evaluate the performance of all its Public Employment Services’ staff and Employment Offices, against predefined qualitative and quantitative indicators and targets. o The public employment service’ staff of the Ministry of Labour and Social Welfare, have the capacity and the tools to implement different active labour market programmes, including the newly activated Self-Employment Programme (SEP). o As part of the establishment of the Employment Agency, the public relations concept and materials are prepared and adopted by MLSW. o Coordination initiated and strengthened between the employment offices in the northern municipalities and the regional employment office of Mitrovica. o The number of active registered job seekers with the PES has increased by 13%, which means that 12,597 job seekers have chosen PES to search for a job, receive different types of training or participate in almp (January-August 2015). On the other hand, 9,574 new vacancies have been announced in PES by private sector companies, a 46% increase from the annual performance of 2014.
Skills development opportunities and job creation o 563 young women and men jobseekers supported to gain skills and find employment opportunities in private enterprises through different active labour market programmes, such as the on-the-job training (OJT), wage subsidy programme (WSP) and the self-employment programme (SEP). 47% of the beneficiaries are women.

TargetI.1: % youth (15-24) benefiting from almps is increased at least for 5% TargetI.2: % women benefiting from almps is increased at least for 10% TargetI.3: % almps beneficiaries from minorities is increased at least for 3% Target 4: At least 910 readmitted persons benefit from almps Target 5: At least 25% of almp beneficiaries are readmitted women Target 6: At least 40% of beneficiaries are readmitted non-majority communities

description.narrative: Enhanced knowledge base on labour
policy, planning and administration
Indicator II.1: Number of policy analysis and briefs produced

comment.narrative: Baseline II.1: Limited number of policy analysis and briefs developed on the labour market supply and demand

5.1. One analytical report (LFS) is produced 5.2. One policy analysis is produced on economic cost of domestic labour 5.3. Six sector skills needs surveys are conducted and produced 5.4. Three public discussions are organized

o Kosovo Agency for Statistics has prepared and launched the Labour Force Survey 2014, providing detailed information on the main labour market indicators in Kosovo. The report has been widely used by various research institutions and policy makers. o Labour Force Survey team within KAS is able to prepare the database, indicators and report for LFS 2015, with less external technical support as a result of the first training delivered to KAS team.
Target: At least 3 policy analysis and briefs are produced

description.narrative: Feasible modalities to established
policy, planning and administration
Indicator III.1: Feasibility study is developed by Q3 2015 (Yes/No)

comment.narrative: Baseline III.1: There are no proposed modalities in place for establishment of an Employment Fund
6.1: Feasibility study on creation of sustainable financing for almps is developed 6.2. Short term and medium term action oriented costed plans prepared and endorsed by MLSW
The feasibility study cannot be initiated before the Employment Agency has been established and is functional. Therefore, the activities under this output are yet to be commenced.
6.1: Feasibility study on creation of sustainable financing for almps is developed 6.2. Short term and medium term action oriented costed plans prepared and endorsed by MLSW

description.narrative: Support to Ministry of Education to establish an Education Information System that would enhance the data collection and analysis as well as evidence based policy making
policy, planning and administration
1. Edu system is developed 2. Edu system is integrated within LMIS

comment.narrative: Baseline 1: No existant Edu Info System which enables the collection of data in a gender sensitive manner Basline 2: No higher education data exists in LMIS

Install the Edu Info System which will enable the collection of data in a gender sensitive manner Edu Info system is linked to LMIS providing information on the labour supply (disaggregated by gender)

title.narrative: Diaspora Engagement for Economic Development II

description.narrative: The objective of the programme is to enhance the contribution of diasp. to poverty reduction in the short-term and to sustainable, local ec. development through facilitating th investment and saving among migrants and remit.-receiving households.

title.narrative: Diaspora Engagement for Economic Development II

description.narrative: The main goals of this project are as following: to strengthen cap. of Kosovo authorities to implement the Nat. Strategy for Diaspora; to increase cap. to facilitate migrants’ investments; strengthen cap. of remit. recipients.
policy, planning and administration
Effective judicial and policing institutions established and contribute to increased personal security.
Firearms Explosives Risk Mitigation
Defence - policy, planning and administration

comment.narrative: Law on Weapons and Law on Weapons, Ammunition and related equipment for state security institutions were amended as well as 08 secondary legislation in full harmonization with the EU regulations. Concept notes for protection of critical infrastructure as well preventing violent extremism were adopted. Kosovo stakeholders were fully trained in fighting the conversion of blank firing weapons and secure stockpile management of weapons and ammunition. Small arms survey was implemented.

1.1.Legal framework upgraded and in line with UN, OSCE and EU standards 1.2. Gun crime intelligence desk established and operational 1.3. Destruction of 1500 weapons released by court. The project will advocate women participation in the working groups and ensure gender sensitivity during the amendments of the laws. 1.1. PVE strategy implemented according to action plan 1.2. Training on bounce resilience tools and Channel Referral mechanism implemented and used in community resilience activities 1.3. Referral mechanism established and operational Gender disaggregated data on PVE and referrals will be collected. Special focus will be given on the impact of violent extremism on gender as well the role of gender during the radicalization process of prevention of mobilization. 1.1. 3 coordinated activities undertaken by MoIA and Police 1.2. 2 priority activities addressing women security concerns implemented 1.3. 2 DPS officials trained 1.4. Implementation of 2 priority community safety actions at the local level

title.narrative: Support to strengthen the Rule of Law in Kosovo

description.narrative: - Percentage of KJI candidates for initial programme graduates pas the final exam and appointed as a judges and prosecutors. - Percentage of candidates who pass the bar exam Bar Exam. - 3% decrease of the cases court backlog as result of harmonized of the Judicial practice.

comment.narrative: - Lack of programme for KJI January-June 2015. -Bar Exam procedures lack transparency.Bar Exam is not harmonized with European standards. -446.254 number of cases pending in Basic Courts, lack of judicial practices.

- Kosovo Judicial Institute (KJI) draft a three year strategy. - Bar Exam procedures are fully transparent and accessible to all minority groups in Kosovo. -Appeal and Basic Courts have harmonized Legal Practice in place, increasing as a result court efficiency.

-The KJI’s Strategic Plan (2015-2018) drafted. -Judicial/ Bar Exam Manual published in Albanian and Serbian Languages and published on the web-site -Guidelines for harmonizing judicial practices (criminal and civil field) at the Basic Courts and Court of Appeal are finalized and published

description.narrative: The objective of the proposed project is to improve CSOs capacity to participate in an informed and competent manner in environmental policy formulation and natural resource management, collaborate in decision-making on key issues.

The project goal is to promote the joint management of the shared water resources of the White Drin Basin as part of the planned activities to foster joint management of the transboundary Drin River Basin.
Environment - policy, planning and administration

1. The Transboundary Diagnostic Analysis of the Extended Drin River Basin, in accordance with the WFD, and identifying main issues of transboundary concern and drivers of change, integrating the White Drin sub-basin, is completed and approved by countries. 2. Information management system containing data gathered through the TDA is established. 3. Visioning process for the White Drin is part of and complements the visioning process at the Drin basin level. The Shared Vision contained in the Drin MoU -updated in consistency with the findings of the TDA, and containing indication of environmental quality objectives (horizon 20 years), relevant indicators, and strategic development lines and priorities- is agreed upon by the countries. 4. A Strategic Action Program (SAP with horizon 5 years) consistent with the updated Shared Vision and the Drin MoU, addressing main issues of transboundary concern and containing concrete actions at the national and regional levels, is formulated. 5. Partnership Conference, aimed at raising awareness and interest of the international community and ODA providers on sustaining countries commitment to SAP implementation. 6. The three Drin Core Group (DCG) Expert Working Groups (EWG) become fully operational making it possible for the DCG to assume the full range of responsibilities stemming from the Drin MoU, as well as promoting gender equal particiaption in line with UNDP GE Strategy. 7. Inter-ministerial Committee (or equivalent body) is established in Kosovo to assist the Secretariat of the Inter-ministerial Water Council with the coordination of country response to guidance of the DCG. 8. A Strategic Action Program (SAP with horizon 5 years) is adopted by the countries, including Kosovo. 9. DCG members, DCG working group members, water and land managers, policy makers and other practitioners are trained in surface/groundwater management, IWRM, implementation of international policy instruments (WFD, UNECE Water Conv

comment.narrative:
Project countries have pursued the management of the shared water resources of the Drin River Basin, both surface and groundwater, predominantly from a national perspective. Countries are at different levels with regard to the EU accession, and implementation of the WFD including the preparation of RBM plans; when RBM plans are being prepared, this is not done in coordination with neighboring countries. Bilateral and multi-lateral agreements concerning lake sub- basins are in place (Ohrid, Prespa, Skadar), but coordination, recognition of transboundary issues at Drin basin level and overall IWRM approach are lacking.
Information and data related to the management of Drin Basin are dispersed among countries and institutions. Countries adopt fragmented approach to water resources utilization and environmental protection with little consideration of transboundary implications and freshwater ecosystems sustainability. A Shared Vision for the management of the Drin Basin has been developed through a multi-stakeholders process and adopted by the Drin Riparians as part of the Drin MoU. Nevertheless, this Shared Vision needs to be developed further to include environmental quality objectives and relevant indicators, and fully incorporate Kosovo’s contributions.
Lack of an overarching basin-wide science based framework for the implementation of the medium and long term priority actions in view of achieving the overall aims and objectives of the Drin MoU, and of the updated Vision hinders the formulation of coherent policies, legislative reforms and identification of investments targeted to the sustainable utilization of the Basin’s water resources and dependent ecosystems, and their integrated management. Donor interest in the region, technical assistance and investments do not respond to a strategic vision to address transboundary issues in the Drin Basin and sub- basins, including the White Drin, in an integrated manner. The institutional structure for the implementatio
Establishment of the bodies to monitor and oversee project results.
The bodies to monitor and oversee the project results established, inception meeting and the first steering committee meeting held.

description.narrative: - Mechanism established and funcional - Number of assesments conducted and people and businesses benefited from advisory services - Number of women and youth benefitted from the programs

comment.narrative: - No mechanism in place or functional

- Establish a coordination mechanism between local and central authorities to facilitate the transfer of forestry management responsibilities to the Kosovo Forestry Agency (KFA) - Identify potential beneficiaries, private forest owners and potential entrepreneurs in the forestry sector - Support development of forest-related businesses and promote entrepreneurship initiatives, including provision of grants and other subsidies, including advisory support - Promote forestry related self-employment programmes for women and youth and support access to markets - Promote active employment measures, focusing on young women and men, in relevant sectors -Provide training to potential beneficiaries on how to apply for grants offered by the Ministry for Agriculture, Forestry and Rural Development. Provide post mentoring and advisory services to grantees.
